bibl.title: Memorandum of talk with Sylvanus Griswold Morley, by Laura Armistead Carter, December 12, 1928

div1.p: Carter writes up notes from a talk with Morley about maps, illustrations, and photographs for the History of Yellow Fever. Reference is also made to Spanish and English translations from the Book of Chilan Balam of Tizimin that Morley has supplied to Carter.

div1.head: Memorandum of talk with Sylvanus Griswold Morley, by Laura Armistead Carter, December 12, 1928
div1.p:
Re talk with Dr. Sylvanus G. Morley, Dec. 12/28
at Carnehgien Institution,
Washington, D. C.

A: Re filling in our three outline maps: Plate 3. Mercator's projec-
tion West Coast of Africa and adjacent islands with East Coast Middle,
North and South America, and adjacent islands. This to show chance
crosees-infection (yellow fever) between the two continents.

Plate 4-a and Plate 4-b: Outlines identical (Middle America,
Nothrth Coast of South America and islands in the Caribbean). Plate
4-a, however, to be filled in with centers of Pre-Columbian population:
Plate 4-b with those after Spanish Conquest. Plate 4-b also to be
so filled in as to illustrate the wanderings of Ojeda and Nicuesa etc.

Dr. Morley deeply regrets that circumstances have arisen which will
make it impossible for him to attend to having these maps filled in,
as he had undertaken to do in 1926.

Dr. Morley suggests that in sending our outline' maps (or, as
Dr. Leake thinks might be safer, photostats of somethat reduced size)
we ask whoever is selected to fill them them in to indicate in pencil
and by number the settlements, towns, etc. to be inserted on the
finished maps, with an accompanying legend giving the names corres-
ponding to these numbers, and, in cases where there has been a de-
cided change in nomenclature, which might confuse the modern reader,
that both the original and present name be given; vid. (Española: His-
pañola, Santo Domingo, Haiti): [unclear] As also A Mina (Elmina)

Incidentally, whoever fills in these maps should have a readable
copy of Father's Ms (or rather of the part relating thereto).

A-2: Re the filling in of Plate 4-a (Pre-Columbian centers of
population) Dr. Morely suggests that we ask Dr. H. J. Spinden of Har-
vard, to do this for us. He considers Dr. Spinden the very best man
available. Of course, proper acknowledgement of Dr. Spinden's assis-
assis-
Page 2
tance would appear in the book. Dr. Spinden's address is:
Dr. H. J. Spinden,
Peabody Museum,
Divinity Avenue,
Cambridge, Massachusetts.

A-3: Re filling in of outline maps (Plate 3 and Plate 4-b), Dr.
Morley considers (1) that Mr. Jameson, of the Library of Congress, would
be the best man we could get, partly on account of his being on the
spot. If Mr. Jameson is too busy, Morley suggests, in the following
order, (2) Dr. James A. Robertson, Editor Florida Historical Society
Publications, 54 Flower Street, Takomah Park, Washington D. C.
(3) Dr. Clarence H. Haring, Dept. of History, Harvard University and
(4) Dr. Charles W. Hackett, Dept of American (?) History, University of Texas,
Austin, Texas.

A-4 (1) Tell Jack that Admiral Rodman says Plate-3 (Mercator's
projection) should be “blocked off” by one Captain Dempff, an authority
on such work, before being filled in. Kempff is a friend of Rodman's
and, Rodman' says, will be glad to do it. Rodman states that maps
of Mercator's projection are apt to become increasingly inaccurate
the farther they go from the equator and that this should be looked
into with our outline. Of course, we only want a map to indicate
epidemiological conditions, but if one can have it unusually good
with very little extra trouble it might be worth while. Que le parece?

(2) Ask Jack for what [unclear] era we should have this map (Merca-
tor's projection) filled in. The historic (or rather pre-historic)
part for African yellow fever ends with Lind and Schotte--latter part
of Xviii th. Century. However, Father's epidemiological argument
for both the Americas and Africagoes was continued to June 1925.

(3) If Jack doesn't like Plate 3 (Mercator's projection) ask
him how he likes the one in vol. ii, on page 1229, Byam and Archibald's
Maps. → Mem. Gen. Alan Johnson's suggestion re “ Span-Am. Soc”
of N.Y. (Hispanic?). J.L.'s re Pan-American
Archibald's
Page 3.
Practice of Medicine in the Tropics. Oxford Press, (1922). Only,
if he prefers this, we'd have to have more islands inserted both
off the African Coast and that of the Americas (Middle and South).

B: Re incomplete bibliographic cards, dealing with Mayan
chronology etc., Morley gave me data and addresses of other authori-
ties on the subject), through which sources I hope to complete most of
these references: (five in all), I took a taxi full of books to the
Carnegie and we cleared up a good many things thereby, which would
have been very difficult for me to handle otherwise.

C: Re the three new excerpts from the Book of Chilam Balamof
of Tizimin, of which Morley sent me the Spanish text in 1926, and
which (in their allusion to “Vómitos de sangre”) strengthen Father's
argument as to the absence of yellow fever in Pre-Columbian times,
Morley has promised to do his utmost to have all the material sent
from Yucatan before we go to press. In this connection see enclosed
letter of transmissiontransmittal to Morley (Dec. 12/28), enclosing Spanish text.
I am also herein enclosing English translation of the above. It is
important and I hope we will get the Mayan text in time to use it in
a foot note.

D: Re illustrations published by the Carnegie Institution, of
which offer has been made us to avail ourselves: Dr. Morley and I
have (tentatively--i. e. subject to Dr. Frost's approval) decided that
those best suited to our purpose would be (b) the Panoramas of Mexican
Cities by Dr. W. H. Holmes (this to show their extent and hence capa-
bility of serving as endemic foci, had yellow fever existed in Pre-
Columbian times) and (b) Carnegie publication (1928) No. 11, 1st.
Photo. (b') Carnegie publication (1927) No. 12, 2nd. photo. These,
and such others as we might select the high state of art and archi-
tecture (if we can separate them!) prevalent among the Mayas at this
time.
Page 4.

For copies of these illustrations, Dr. Morley has referred me
to Dr. Frank Bunker, Editor of the Carnegie publications: Carnegie
Institution of Washington, Sixteenth and P Streets, N. W. Washing-
ton, D.C. Dr. Bunker will let us have photographs, for reproduction,
of anything already published by the Carnegie Institution, suitable
acknowledgment being, of course, made for this courtesy.

Enclosures: Of three new excerpts from book of Chilam Balam of
Tizimin, implying arrival of “Vomito(s) de sangre” with
the Spaniards and tentative translation thereof:. Also,
carbon of letter transmitting them to Dr. Morley, Decem-
ber 12, 1928.
